slides.title: SQL & Databases
slides.subtitle:
Fundamentals of Relational Database Management
From Basics to Advanced Concepts

list.text: SQL vs NoSQL - Choosing the Right Tool

box.content: Organized collection of structured information stored electronically

list.text: Purpose - Store, manage, and retrieve data efficiently

note.text: Fun fact: The first computerized databases appeared in the 1960s, but humans have been keeping databases (ledgers, records) for thousands of years!

list.text: NoSQL Use Cases - Real-time apps, big data, IoT

box.content: Standard language for managing and manipulating relational databases

list.text: History - Developed by IBM in 1970s, ANSI standard
Universal - Works across all major database systems
Declarative - Specify WHAT you want, not HOW
Atomicity - All or nothing: transactions complete fully or not at all
Consistency - Database rules preserved: valid state before and after
Isolation - Concurrent transactions don't interfere: appear serialized
Durability - Committed changes persist: survive system failures
Row/Record - Single data item in a table
Primary Key - Unique identifier for each row
Foreign Key - Reference to another table's primary key

users Table:

Components:
â€¢ Table: users
â€¢ Rows: 3 user records  
â€¢ Columns: user_id, username, email, birth_date, created_at
â€¢ Primary Key: user_id
â€¢ Foreign Keys: (none in this simple table)

-- Create a new database
CREATE DATABASE company;

-- Switch to the database
USE company;  -- MySQL
\c company    -- PostgreSQL

-- Show all databases
SHOW DATABASES;  -- MySQL
\l              -- PostgreSQL

-- Drop database (careful!)
DROP DATABASE company;

-- Create database with options
CREATE DATABASE ecommerce
CHARACTER SET utf8mb4
COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci;

CREATE TABLE employees (
    employee_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    first_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    last_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    email VARCHAR(100) UNIQUE NOT NULL,
    hire_date DATE NOT NULL,
    salary DECIMAL(10,2) CHECK (salary > 0),
    department_id INT,
    FOREIGN KEY (department_id) REFERENCES departments(department_id)
);

-- Show table structure
DESCRIBE employees;  -- MySQL
\d employees        -- PostgreSQL

-- Create table from existing table
CREATE TABLE employees_backup AS 
SELECT * FROM employees;

-- Sort by single column
SELECT * FROM employees 
ORDER BY last_name ASC;

-- Sort by multiple columns
SELECT * FROM employees 
ORDER BY department_id ASC, salary DESC;

-- Limit results
SELECT * FROM employees 
ORDER BY hire_date DESC 
LIMIT 10;

-- Pagination (different syntax by database)
-- MySQL
SELECT * FROM employees 
ORDER BY employee_id 
LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20;  -- Skip 20, take 10

-- PostgreSQL  
SELECT * FROM employees 
ORDER BY employee_id 
LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20;

-- SQL Server
SELECT * FROM employees 
ORDER BY employee_id 
OFFSET 20 ROWS FETCH NEXT 10 ROWS ONLY;

list.text: INNER JOIN - Only matching records from both tables
LEFT JOIN - All records from left, matching from right
RIGHT JOIN - All records from right, matching from left
FULL JOIN - All records from both tables
CROSS JOIN - Cartesian product of both tables

box.code:
-- INNER JOIN: Employees with departments
SELECT e.first_name, e.last_name, d.department_name
FROM employees e
INNER JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.department_id;

-- LEFT JOIN: All employees, with department if exists
SELECT e.first_name, e.last_name, d.department_name
FROM employees e
LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.department_id;

-- Multiple joins
SELECT 
    e.first_name, 
    e.last_name, 
    d.department_name,
    m.first_name as manager_name
FROM employees e
LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.department_id
LEFT JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.employee_id;

-- Self join: Employees and their managers
SELECT 
    emp.first_name as employee_name,
    mgr.first_name as manager_name
FROM employees emp
LEFT JOIN employees mgr ON emp.manager_id = mgr.employee_id;

-- Tables with primary and foreign keys
CREATE TABLE departments (
    department_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    department_name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    manager_id INT
);

CREATE TABLE employees (
    employee_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    first_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    last_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    department_id INT,
    manager_id INT,
    -- Foreign key constraints
    FOREIGN KEY (department_id) 
        REFERENCES departments(department_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (manager_id) 
        REFERENCES employees(employee_id)
);

-- Foreign key actions
FOREIGN KEY (department_id) 
REFERENCES departments(department_id)
ON DELETE CASCADE    -- Delete employees when department deleted
ON UPDATE SET NULL;  -- Set NULL if department_id changes

list.text: Atomic Values - Each cell contains single value
Unique Column Names - No duplicate column names
Single Data Type - Each column same data type
Single Purpose Columns - All non-key columns depend on full primary key
No Partial Dependencies - Remove columns that depend on part of key
No Transitive Dependencies - Remove columns that depend on other non-key columns
Like Book Index - Fast lookup without scanning everything

box.code:
-- Single column index
CREATE INDEX idx_employees_last_name 
ON employees(last_name);

-- Composite index (multiple columns)
CREATE INDEX idx_employees_dept_salary 
ON employees(department_id, salary);

-- Unique index
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX idx_employees_email 
ON employees(email);

-- Partial index (PostgreSQL)
CREATE INDEX idx_high_salary_employees 
ON employees(salary) 
WHERE salary > 100000;

-- Show indexes
SHOW INDEX FROM employees;  -- MySQL
\di employees               -- PostgreSQL

-- Drop index
DROP INDEX idx_employees_last_name;

-- Count employees per department
SELECT 
    department_id,
    COUNT(*) as employee_count
FROM employees
GROUP BY department_id;

-- Average salary by department
SELECT 
    department_id,
    AVG(salary) as avg_salary,
    MAX(salary) as max_salary,
    MIN(salary) as min_salary
FROM employees
GROUP BY department_id;

-- Multiple grouping columns
SELECT 
    department_id,
    EXTRACT(YEAR FROM hire_date) as hire_year,
    COUNT(*) as hired_count
FROM employees
GROUP BY department_id, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM hire_date)
ORDER BY department_id, hire_year;

-- Departments with more than 10 employees
SELECT 
    department_id,
    COUNT(*) as employee_count
FROM employees
GROUP BY department_id
HAVING COUNT(*) > 10;

-- Departments with average salary > 70000
SELECT 
    department_id,
    AVG(salary) as avg_salary
FROM employees
GROUP BY department_id
HAVING AVG(salary) > 70000;

-- Multiple HAVING conditions
SELECT 
    department_id,
    COUNT(*) as employee_count,
    AVG(salary) as avg_salary
FROM employees
GROUP BY department_id
HAVING 
    COUNT(*) > 5 
    AND AVG(salary) BETWEEN 50000 AND 100000
ORDER BY avg_salary DESC;

list.text: Virtual Table - Stored query, not actual data
Security - Hide sensitive columns or complex logic
No Storage - Data not duplicated, always current

box.code:
-- Simple view
CREATE VIEW employee_directory AS
SELECT 
    employee_id,
    first_name,
    last_name,
    email,
    department_name
FROM employees e
JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.department_id;

-- Use the view
SELECT * FROM employee_directory 
WHERE department_name = 'Engineering';

-- Updatable view (simple case)
CREATE VIEW active_employees AS
SELECT * FROM employees 
WHERE status = 'active';

-- Complex view with aggregation
CREATE VIEW department_stats AS
SELECT 
    d.department_name,
    COUNT(e.employee_id) as employee_count,
    AVG(e.salary) as avg_salary
FROM departments d
LEFT JOIN employees e ON d.department_id = e.department_id
GROUP BY d.department_id, d.department_name;

-- Materialized view (PostgreSQL)
CREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW sales_summary AS
SELECT 
    product_id,
    SUM(quantity) as total_sold,
    SUM(amount) as total_revenue
FROM sales
GROUP BY product_id;

-- Refresh materialized view
REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW sales_summary;

-- MySQL stored procedure
DELIMITER //
CREATE PROCEDURE GetEmployeeCountByDepartment(IN dept_id INT)
BEGIN
    SELECT COUNT(*) as employee_count
    FROM employees
    WHERE department_id = dept_id;
END //
DELIMITER ;

-- Call procedure
CALL GetEmployeeCountByDepartment(3);

-- PostgreSQL function
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION get_department_employees(dept_id INT)
RETURNS TABLE(
    employee_id INT,
    first_name VARCHAR,
    last_name VARCHAR
) AS $$
BEGIN
    RETURN QUERY
    SELECT e.employee_id, e.first_name, e.last_name
    FROM employees e
    WHERE e.department_id = dept_id;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;

-- Call function
SELECT * FROM get_department_employees(3);

list.text: FOREIGN KEY - References primary key in another table
NOT NULL - Column cannot contain null values
UNIQUE - All values in column must be unique

Relationship Types:
â€¢ 1:1 - One-to-One
â€¢ 1:N - One-to-Many  
â€¢ N:M - Many-to-Many (requires junction table)

-- MySQL EXPLAIN
EXPLAIN SELECT * FROM employees WHERE last_name = 'Smith';

-- PostgreSQL EXPLAIN
EXPLAIN ANALYZE SELECT * FROM employees WHERE last_name = 'Smith';

-- Sample EXPLAIN output interpretation:
â€¢ type: ALL = Full table scan (bad)
â€¢ type: ref = Using index (good)
â€¢ rows: Estimated rows examined
â€¢ key: Index used
â€¢ Extra: Additional operations

-- Common optimization tips:
1. Use indexes on WHERE, JOIN, ORDER BY columns
2. Avoid SELECT * - specify only needed columns
3. Use LIMIT to restrict result sets
4. Avoid functions on indexed columns in WHERE
5. Use EXISTS instead of IN for large subqueries
6. Normalize tables to reduce redundancy
7. Use appropriate data types

-- Bad: Function on indexed column
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE YEAR(hire_date) = 2023;

-- Good: Use range on raw column  
SELECT * FROM employees 
WHERE hire_date BETWEEN '2023-01-01' AND '2023-12-31';

-- E-commerce database schema
CREATE TABLE customers (
    customer_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    first_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    last_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    email VARCHAR(100) UNIQUE NOT NULL,
    password_hash VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

CREATE TABLE products (
    product_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    name VARCHAR(200) NOT NULL,
    description TEXT,
    price DECIMAL(10,2) NOT NULL,
    stock_quantity INT DEFAULT 0,
    category_id INT,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (category_id) REFERENCES categories(category_id)
);

CREATE TABLE categories (
    category_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    parent_category_id INT,
    FOREIGN KEY (parent_category_id) REFERENCES categories(category_id)
);

CREATE TABLE orders (
    order_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    customer_id INT NOT NULL,
    order_date TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    total_amount DECIMAL(10,2) NOT NULL,
    status ENUM('pending', 'confirmed', 'shipped', 'delivered', 'cancelled'),
    shipping_address TEXT,
    FOREIGN KEY (customer_id) REFERENCES customers(customer_id)
);

CREATE TABLE order_items (
    order_id INT,
    product_id INT,
    quantity INT NOT NULL,
    unit_price DECIMAL(10,2) NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (order_id, product_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (order_id) REFERENCES orders(order_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (product_id) REFERENCES products(product_id)
);

-- Monthly sales trends
SELECT 
    EXTRACT(YEAR_MONTH FROM order_date) as year_month,
    COUNT(*) as order_count,
    SUM(total_amount) as total_revenue,
    AVG(total_amount) as avg_order_value
FROM orders
GROUP BY EXTRACT(YEAR_MONTH FROM order_date)
ORDER BY year_month;

-- Customer lifetime value
SELECT 
    customer_id,
    COUNT(*) as total_orders,
    SUM(total_amount) as total_spent,
    AVG(total_amount) as avg_order_value,
    MAX(order_date) as last_order_date
FROM orders
GROUP BY customer_id
HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
ORDER BY total_spent DESC;

-- Product performance
SELECT 
    p.name as product_name,
    c.name as category_name,
    SUM(oi.quantity) as total_sold,
    SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) as total_revenue
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.product_id
JOIN categories c ON p.category_id = c.category_id
GROUP BY p.product_id, p.name, c.name
ORDER BY total_revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;

list.text: Mode Analytics - SQL tutorial with real datasets
What's the difference between WHERE and HAVING?
When would you use a LEFT JOIN vs INNER JOIN?
What are the ACID properties and why are they important?
How do you prevent SQL injection attacks?
What's the purpose of database normalization?
SQL is essential for data management and analysis
ACID properties ensure data integrity and reliability
JOINs connect related data across multiple tables
Normalization reduces redundancy and improves integrity
SQL skills are valuable across many tech roles
